36#ifndef __I915_GEM_GTT_H__
37#define __I915_GEM_GTT_H__
38
39struct drm_i915_file_private;
40
41typedef uint32_t gen6_pte_t;
42typedef uint64_t gen8_pte_t;
43typedef uint64_t gen8_pde_t;
44typedef uint64_t gen8_ppgtt_pdpe_t;
45typedef uint64_t gen8_ppgtt_pml4e_t;
46
47#define gtt_total_entries(gtt) ((gtt).base.total >> PAGE_SHIFT)
48
49
50/* gen6-hsw has bit 11-4 for physical addr bit 39-32 */
51#define GEN6_GTT_ADDR_ENCODE(addr) ((addr) | (((addr) >> 28) & 0xff0))
52#define GEN6_PTE_ADDR_ENCODE(addr) GEN6_GTT_ADDR_ENCODE(addr)
53#define GEN6_PDE_ADDR_ENCODE(addr) GEN6_GTT_ADDR_ENCODE(addr)
54#define GEN6_PTE_CACHE_LLC (2 << 1)
55#define GEN6_PTE_UNCACHED (1 << 1)
56#define GEN6_PTE_VALID (1 << 0)
57
58#define I915_PTES(pte_len) (PAGE_SIZE / (pte_len))
59#define I915_PTE_MASK(pte_len) (I915_PTES(pte_len) - 1)
60#define I915_PDES 512
61#define I915_PDE_MASK (I915_PDES - 1)
62#define NUM_PTE(pde_shift) (1 << (pde_shift - PAGE_SHIFT))
63
64#define GEN6_PTES I915_PTES(sizeof(gen6_pte_t))
65#define GEN6_PD_SIZE (I915_PDES * PAGE_SIZE)
66#define GEN6_PD_ALIGN (PAGE_SIZE * 16)
67#define GEN6_PDE_SHIFT 22
68#define GEN6_PDE_VALID (1 << 0)
69
70#define GEN7_PTE_CACHE_L3_LLC (3 << 1)
71
72#define BYT_PTE_SNOOPED_BY_CPU_CACHES (1 << 2)
73#define BYT_PTE_WRITEABLE (1 << 1)
74
75/* Cacheability Control is a 4-bit value. The low three bits are stored in bits
76 * 3:1 of the PTE, while the fourth bit is stored in bit 11 of the PTE.
77 */
78#define HSW_CACHEABILITY_CONTROL(bits) ((((bits) & 0x7) << 1) | \
79 (((bits) & 0x8) << (11 - 3)))
80#define HSW_WB_LLC_AGE3 HSW_CACHEABILITY_CONTROL(0x2)
81#define HSW_WB_LLC_AGE0 HSW_CACHEABILITY_CONTROL(0x3)
82#define HSW_WB_ELLC_LLC_AGE3 HSW_CACHEABILITY_CONTROL(0x8)
83#define HSW_WB_ELLC_LLC_AGE0 HSW_CACHEABILITY_CONTROL(0xb)
84#define HSW_WT_ELLC_LLC_AGE3 HSW_CACHEABILITY_CONTROL(0x7)
85#define HSW_WT_ELLC_LLC_AGE0 HSW_CACHEABILITY_CONTROL(0x6)
86#define HSW_PTE_UNCACHED (0)
87#define HSW_GTT_ADDR_ENCODE(addr) ((addr) | (((addr) >> 28) & 0x7f0))
88#define HSW_PTE_ADDR_ENCODE(addr) HSW_GTT_ADDR_ENCODE(addr)
89
90/* GEN8 legacy style address is defined as a 3 level page table:
91 * 31:30 | 29:21 | 20:12 | 11:0
92 * PDPE | PDE | PTE | offset
93 * The difference as compared to normal x86 3 level page table is the PDPEs are
94 * programmed via register.
95 *
96 * GEN8 48b legacy style address is defined as a 4 level page table:
97 * 47:39 | 38:30 | 29:21 | 20:12 | 11:0
98 * PML4E | PDPE | PDE | PTE | offset
99 */
100#define GEN8_PML4ES_PER_PML4 512
101#define GEN8_PML4E_SHIFT 39
102#define GEN8_PML4E_MASK (GEN8_PML4ES_PER_PML4 - 1)
103#define GEN8_PDPE_SHIFT 30
104/* NB: GEN8_PDPE_MASK is untrue for 32b platforms, but it has no impact on 32b page
105 * tables */
106#define GEN8_PDPE_MASK 0x1ff
107#define GEN8_PDE_SHIFT 21
108#define GEN8_PDE_MASK 0x1ff
109#define GEN8_PTE_SHIFT 12
110#define GEN8_PTE_MASK 0x1ff
111#define GEN8_LEGACY_PDPES 4
112#define GEN8_PTES I915_PTES(sizeof(gen8_pte_t))
113
114#define I915_PDPES_PER_PDP(dev) (USES_FULL_48BIT_PPGTT(dev) ?\
115 GEN8_PML4ES_PER_PML4 : GEN8_LEGACY_PDPES)
116
117#define PPAT_UNCACHED_INDEX (_PAGE_PWT | _PAGE_PCD)
118#define PPAT_CACHED_PDE_INDEX 0 /* WB LLC */
119#define PPAT_CACHED_INDEX _PAGE_PAT /* WB LLCeLLC */
120#define PPAT_DISPLAY_ELLC_INDEX _PAGE_PCD /* WT eLLC */
121
122#define CHV_PPAT_SNOOP (1<<6)
123#define GEN8_PPAT_AGE(x) (x<<4)
124#define GEN8_PPAT_LLCeLLC (3<<2)
125#define GEN8_PPAT_LLCELLC (2<<2)
126#define GEN8_PPAT_LLC (1<<2)
127#define GEN8_PPAT_WB (3<<0)
128#define GEN8_PPAT_WT (2<<0)
129#define GEN8_PPAT_WC (1<<0)
130#define GEN8_PPAT_UC (0<<0)
131#define GEN8_PPAT_ELLC_OVERRIDE (0<<2)
132#define GEN8_PPAT(i, x) ((uint64_t) (x) << ((i) * 8))
133
134enum i915_ggtt_view_type {
135 I915_GGTT_VIEW_NORMAL = 0,
136 I915_GGTT_VIEW_ROTATED,
137 I915_GGTT_VIEW_PARTIAL,
138};
139
140struct intel_rotation_info {
141 unsigned int height;
142 unsigned int pitch;
143 unsigned int uv_offset;
144 uint32_t pixel_format;
145 uint64_t fb_modifier;
146 unsigned int width_pages, height_pages;
147 uint64_t size;
148 unsigned int width_pages_uv, height_pages_uv;
149 uint64_t size_uv;
150 unsigned int uv_start_page;
151};
152
153struct i915_ggtt_view {
154 enum i915_ggtt_view_type type;
155
156 union {
157 struct {
158 u64 offset;
159 unsigned int size;
160 } partial;
161 } params;
162
163#ifdef __NetBSD__
164 bus_dmamap_t pages;
165#else
166 struct sg_table *pages;
167#endif
168
169 union {
170 struct intel_rotation_info rotation_info;
171 };
172};
173
174extern const struct i915_ggtt_view i915_ggtt_view_normal;
175extern const struct i915_ggtt_view i915_ggtt_view_rotated;
176
177enum i915_cache_level;
178
179/**
180 * A VMA represents a GEM BO that is bound into an address space. Therefore, a
181 * VMA's presence cannot be guaranteed before binding, or after unbinding the
182 * object into/from the address space.
183 *
184 * To make things as simple as possible (ie. no refcounting), a VMA's lifetime
185 * will always be <= an objects lifetime. So object refcounting should cover us.
186 */
187struct i915_vma {
188 struct drm_mm_node node;
189 struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj;
190 struct i915_address_space *vm;
191
192 /** Flags and address space this VMA is bound to */
193#define GLOBAL_BIND (1<<0)
194#define LOCAL_BIND (1<<1)
195 unsigned int bound : 4;
196
197 /**
198 * Support different GGTT views into the same object.
199 * This means there can be multiple VMA mappings per object and per VM.
200 * i915_ggtt_view_type is used to distinguish between those entries.
201 * The default one of zero (I915_GGTT_VIEW_NORMAL) is default and also
202 * assumed in GEM functions which take no ggtt view parameter.
203 */
204 struct i915_ggtt_view ggtt_view;
205
206 /** This object's place on the active/inactive lists */
207 struct list_head mm_list;
208
209 struct list_head vma_link; /* Link in the object's VMA list */
210
211 /** This vma's place in the batchbuffer or on the eviction list */
212 struct list_head exec_list;
213
214 /**
215 * Used for performing relocations during execbuffer insertion.
216 */
217 struct hlist_node exec_node;
218 unsigned long exec_handle;
219 struct drm_i915_gem_exec_object2 *exec_entry;
220
221 /**
222 * How many users have pinned this object in GTT space. The following
223 * users can each hold at most one reference: pwrite/pread, execbuffer
224 * (objects are not allowed multiple times for the same batchbuffer),
225 * and the framebuffer code. When switching/pageflipping, the
226 * framebuffer code has at most two buffers pinned per crtc.
227 *
228 * In the worst case this is 1 + 1 + 1 + 2*2 = 7. That would fit into 3
229 * bits with absolutely no headroom. So use 4 bits. */
230 unsigned int pin_count:4;
231#define DRM_I915_GEM_OBJECT_MAX_PIN_COUNT 0xf
232};
233
234struct i915_page_dma {
235#ifdef __NetBSD__
236 union {
237 bus_dma_segment_t seg;
238 uint32_t ggtt_offset;
239 };
240 bus_dmamap_t map;
241#else
242 struct page *page;
243 union {
244 dma_addr_t daddr;
245
246 /* For gen6/gen7 only. This is the offset in the GGTT
247 * where the page directory entries for PPGTT begin
248 */
249 uint32_t ggtt_offset;
250 };
251#endif
252};
253
254#define px_base(px) (&(px)->base)
255#ifdef __NetBSD__
256#define px_page(px) (px_base(px)->map)
257#define px_dma(px) (px_base(px)->map->dm_segs[0].ds_addr)
258#else
259#define px_page(px) (px_base(px)->page)
260#define px_dma(px) (px_base(px)->daddr)
261#endif
262
263struct i915_page_scratch {
264 struct i915_page_dma base;
265};
266
267struct i915_page_table {
268 struct i915_page_dma base;
269
270 unsigned long *used_ptes;
271};
272
273struct i915_page_directory {
274 struct i915_page_dma base;
275
276 unsigned long *used_pdes;
277 struct i915_page_table *page_table[I915_PDES]; /* PDEs */
278};
279
280struct i915_page_directory_pointer {
281 struct i915_page_dma base;
282
283 unsigned long *used_pdpes;
284 struct i915_page_directory **page_directory;
285};
286
287struct i915_pml4 {
288 struct i915_page_dma base;
289
290 DECLARE_BITMAP(used_pml4es, GEN8_PML4ES_PER_PML4);
291 struct i915_page_directory_pointer *pdps[GEN8_PML4ES_PER_PML4];
292};
293
294struct i915_address_space {
295 struct drm_mm mm;
296 struct drm_device *dev;
297 struct list_head global_link;
298 u64 start; /* Start offset always 0 for dri2 */
299 u64 total; /* size addr space maps (ex. 2GB for ggtt) */
300
301 struct i915_page_scratch *scratch_page;
302 struct i915_page_table *scratch_pt;
303 struct i915_page_directory *scratch_pd;
304 struct i915_page_directory_pointer *scratch_pdp; /* GEN8+ & 48b PPGTT */
305
306 /**
307 * List of objects currently involved in rendering.
308 *
309 * Includes buffers having the contents of their GPU caches
310 * flushed, not necessarily primitives. last_read_req
311 * represents when the rendering involved will be completed.
312 *
313 * A reference is held on the buffer while on this list.
314 */
315 struct list_head active_list;
316
317 /**
318 * LRU list of objects which are not in the ringbuffer and
319 * are ready to unbind, but are still in the GTT.
320 *
321 * last_read_req is NULL while an object is in this list.
322 *
323 * A reference is not held on the buffer while on this list,
324 * as merely being GTT-bound shouldn't prevent its being
325 * freed, and we'll pull it off the list in the free path.
326 */
327 struct list_head inactive_list;
328
329 /* FIXME: Need a more generic return type */
330 gen6_pte_t (*pte_encode)(dma_addr_t addr,
331 enum i915_cache_level level,
332 bool valid, u32 flags); /* Create a valid PTE */
333 /* flags for pte_encode */
334#define PTE_READ_ONLY (1<<0)
335 int (*allocate_va_range)(struct i915_address_space *vm,
336 uint64_t start,
337 uint64_t length);
338 void (*clear_range)(struct i915_address_space *vm,
339 uint64_t start,
340 uint64_t length,
341 bool use_scratch);
342 void (*insert_entries)(struct i915_address_space *vm,
343#ifdef __NetBSD__
344 bus_dmamap_t dmamap,
345#else
346 struct sg_table *st,
347#endif
348 uint64_t start,
349 enum i915_cache_level cache_level, u32 flags);
350 void (*cleanup)(struct i915_address_space *vm);
351 /** Unmap an object from an address space. This usually consists of
352 * setting the valid PTE entries to a reserved scratch page. */
353 void (*unbind_vma)(struct i915_vma *vma);
354 /* Map an object into an address space with the given cache flags. */
355 int (*bind_vma)(struct i915_vma *vma,
356 enum i915_cache_level cache_level,
357 u32 flags);
358};
359
360/* The Graphics Translation Table is the way in which GEN hardware translates a
361 * Graphics Virtual Address into a Physical Address. In addition to the normal
362 * collateral associated with any va->pa translations GEN hardware also has a
363 * portion of the GTT which can be mapped by the CPU and remain both coherent
364 * and correct (in cases like swizzling). That region is referred to as GMADR in
365 * the spec.
366 */
367struct i915_gtt {
368 struct i915_address_space base;
369
370 size_t stolen_size; /* Total size of stolen memory */
371 size_t stolen_usable_size; /* Total size minus BIOS reserved */
372 u64 mappable_end; /* End offset that we can CPU map */
373 struct io_mapping *mappable; /* Mapping to our CPU mappable region */
374 phys_addr_t mappable_base; /* PA of our GMADR */
375
376 /** "Graphics Stolen Memory" holds the global PTEs */
377#ifdef __NetBSD__
378 /*
379 * This is not actually the `Graphics Stolen Memory'; it is the
380 * graphics translation table, which we write to through the
381 * GTTADR/GTTMMADR PCI BAR, and which is backed by `Graphics
382 * GTT Stolen Memory'. That isn't the `Graphics Stolen Memory'
383 * either, although it is stolen from main memory.
384 */
385 bus_space_tag_t bst;
386 bus_space_handle_t bsh;
387 bus_size_t size;
388
389 /* Maximum physical address that can be wired into a GTT entry. */
390 uint64_t max_paddr;
391
392 /* Page freelist for pages limited to the above maximum address. */
393 int pgfl;
394#else
395 void __iomem *gsm;
396#endif
397
398 bool do_idle_maps;
399
400 int mtrr;
401
402 /* global gtt ops */
403 int (*gtt_probe)(struct drm_device *dev, u64 *gtt_total,
404 size_t *stolen, phys_addr_t *mappable_base,
405 u64 *mappable_end);
406};
407
408struct i915_hw_ppgtt {
409 struct i915_address_space base;
410 struct kref ref;
411 struct drm_mm_node node;
412 unsigned long pd_dirty_rings;
413 union {
414 struct i915_pml4 pml4; /* GEN8+ & 48b PPGTT */
415 struct i915_page_directory_pointer pdp; /* GEN8+ */
416 struct i915_page_directory pd; /* GEN6-7 */
417 };
418
419 struct drm_i915_file_private *file_priv;
420
421#ifndef __NetBSD__
422 gen6_pte_t __iomem *pd_addr;
423#endif
424
425 int (*enable)(struct i915_hw_ppgtt *ppgtt);
426 int (*switch_mm)(struct i915_hw_ppgtt *ppgtt,
427 struct drm_i915_gem_request *req);
428 void (*debug_dump)(struct i915_hw_ppgtt *ppgtt, struct seq_file *m);
429};
430
431/* For each pde iterates over every pde between from start until start + length.
432 * If start, and start+length are not perfectly divisible, the macro will round
433 * down, and up as needed. The macro modifies pde, start, and length. Dev is
434 * only used to differentiate shift values. Temp is temp. On gen6/7, start = 0,
435 * and length = 2G effectively iterates over every PDE in the system.
436 *
437 * XXX: temp is not actually needed, but it saves doing the ALIGN operation.
438 */
439#ifdef __NetBSD__ /* ALIGN means something else */
440#define gen6_for_each_pde(pt, pd, start, length, temp, iter) \
441 for (iter = gen6_pde_index(start); \
442 length > 0 && iter < I915_PDES ? \
443 (pt = (pd)->page_table[iter]), 1 : 0; \
444 iter++, \
445 temp = round_up(start+1, 1 << GEN6_PDE_SHIFT) - start, \
446 temp = min_t(unsigned, temp, length), \
447 start += temp, length -= temp)
448#else
449#define gen6_for_each_pde(pt, pd, start, length, temp, iter) \
450 for (iter = gen6_pde_index(start); \
451 length > 0 && iter < I915_PDES ? \
452 (pt = (pd)->page_table[iter]), 1 : 0; \
453 iter++, \
454 temp = ALIGN(start+1, 1 << GEN6_PDE_SHIFT) - start, \
455 temp = min_t(unsigned, temp, length), \
456 start += temp, length -= temp)
457#endif
458
459#define gen6_for_all_pdes(pt, ppgtt, iter) \
460 for (iter = 0; \
461 pt = ppgtt->pd.page_table[iter], iter < I915_PDES; \
462 iter++)
463
464static inline uint32_t i915_pte_index(uint64_t address, uint32_t pde_shift)
465{
466 const uint32_t mask = NUM_PTE(pde_shift) - 1;
467
468 return (address >> PAGE_SHIFT) & mask;
469}
470
471/* Helper to counts the number of PTEs within the given length. This count
472 * does not cross a page table boundary, so the max value would be
473 * GEN6_PTES for GEN6, and GEN8_PTES for GEN8.
474*/
475static inline uint32_t i915_pte_count(uint64_t addr, size_t length,
476 uint32_t pde_shift)
477{
478 const uint64_t mask = ~((1 << pde_shift) - 1);
479 uint64_t end;
480
481 WARN_ON(length == 0);
482 WARN_ON(offset_in_page(addr|length));
483
484 end = addr + length;
485
486 if ((addr & mask) != (end & mask))
487 return NUM_PTE(pde_shift) - i915_pte_index(addr, pde_shift);
488
489 return i915_pte_index(end, pde_shift) - i915_pte_index(addr, pde_shift);
490}
491
492static inline uint32_t i915_pde_index(uint64_t addr, uint32_t shift)
493{
494 return (addr >> shift) & I915_PDE_MASK;
495}
496
497static inline uint32_t gen6_pte_index(uint32_t addr)
498{
499 return i915_pte_index(addr, GEN6_PDE_SHIFT);
500}
501
502static inline size_t gen6_pte_count(uint32_t addr, uint32_t length)
503{
504 return i915_pte_count(addr, length, GEN6_PDE_SHIFT);
505}
506
507static inline uint32_t gen6_pde_index(uint32_t addr)
508{
509 return i915_pde_index(addr, GEN6_PDE_SHIFT);
510}
511
512/* Equivalent to the gen6 version, For each pde iterates over every pde
513 * between from start until start + length. On gen8+ it simply iterates
514 * over every page directory entry in a page directory.
515 */
516#ifdef __NetBSD__ /* ALIGN means something else */
517
518#define gen8_for_each_pde(pt, pd, start, length, temp, iter) \
519 for (iter = gen8_pde_index(start); \
520 length > 0 && iter < I915_PDES ? \
521 (pt = (pd)->page_table[iter]), 1 : 0; \
522 iter++, \
523 temp = round_up(start+1, 1 << GEN8_PDE_SHIFT) - start, \
524 temp = min(temp, length), \
525 start += temp, length -= temp)
526#define gen8_for_each_pdpe(pd, pdp, start, length, temp, iter) \
527 for (iter = gen8_pdpe_index(start); \
528 length > 0 && (iter < I915_PDPES_PER_PDP(dev)) ? \
529 (pd = (pdp)->page_directory[iter]), 1 : 0; \
530 iter++, \
531 temp = round_up(start+1, 1 << GEN8_PDPE_SHIFT) - start, \
532 temp = min(temp, length), \
533 start += temp, length -= temp)
534
535#define gen8_for_each_pml4e(pdp, pml4, start, length, temp, iter) \
536 for (iter = gen8_pml4e_index(start); \
537 length > 0 && iter < GEN8_PML4ES_PER_PML4 ? \
538 (pdp = (pml4)->pdps[iter]), 1 : 0; \
539 iter++, \
540 temp = round_up(start+1, 1ULL << GEN8_PML4E_SHIFT) - start, \
541 temp = min(temp, length), \
542 start += temp, length -= temp)
543
544#else
545
546#define gen8_for_each_pde(pt, pd, start, length, temp, iter) \
547 for (iter = gen8_pde_index(start); \
548 length > 0 && iter < I915_PDES ? \
549 (pt = (pd)->page_table[iter]), 1 : 0; \
550 iter++, \
551 temp = ALIGN(start+1, 1 << GEN8_PDE_SHIFT) - start, \
552 temp = min(temp, length), \
553 start += temp, length -= temp)
554
555#define gen8_for_each_pdpe(pd, pdp, start, length, temp, iter) \
556 for (iter = gen8_pdpe_index(start); \
557 length > 0 && (iter < I915_PDPES_PER_PDP(dev)) ? \
558 (pd = (pdp)->page_directory[iter]), 1 : 0; \
559 iter++, \
560 temp = ALIGN(start+1, 1 << GEN8_PDPE_SHIFT) - start, \
561 temp = min(temp, length), \
562 start += temp, length -= temp)
563
564#define gen8_for_each_pml4e(pdp, pml4, start, length, temp, iter) \
565 for (iter = gen8_pml4e_index(start); \
566 length > 0 && iter < GEN8_PML4ES_PER_PML4 ? \
567 (pdp = (pml4)->pdps[iter]), 1 : 0; \
568 iter++, \
569 temp = ALIGN(start+1, 1ULL << GEN8_PML4E_SHIFT) - start, \
570 temp = min(temp, length), \
571 start += temp, length -= temp)
572#endif
573
574static inline uint32_t gen8_pte_index(uint64_t address)
575{
576 return i915_pte_index(address, GEN8_PDE_SHIFT);
577}
578
579static inline uint32_t gen8_pde_index(uint64_t address)
580{
581 return i915_pde_index(address, GEN8_PDE_SHIFT);
582}
583
584static inline uint32_t gen8_pdpe_index(uint64_t address)
585{
586 return (address >> GEN8_PDPE_SHIFT) & GEN8_PDPE_MASK;
587}
588
589static inline uint32_t gen8_pml4e_index(uint64_t address)
590{
591 return (address >> GEN8_PML4E_SHIFT) & GEN8_PML4E_MASK;
592}
593
594static inline size_t gen8_pte_count(uint64_t address, uint64_t length)
595{
596 return i915_pte_count(address, length, GEN8_PDE_SHIFT);
597}
598
599static inline dma_addr_t
600i915_page_dir_dma_addr(const struct i915_hw_ppgtt *ppgtt, const unsigned n)
601{
602 return test_bit(n, ppgtt->pdp.used_pdpes) ?
603 px_dma(ppgtt->pdp.page_directory[n]) :
604 px_dma(ppgtt->base.scratch_pd);
605}
606
607int i915_gem_gtt_init(struct drm_device *dev);
608void i915_gem_init_global_gtt(struct drm_device *dev);
609void i915_global_gtt_cleanup(struct drm_device *dev);
610
611
612int i915_ppgtt_init(struct drm_device *dev, struct i915_hw_ppgtt *ppgtt);
613int i915_ppgtt_init_hw(struct drm_device *dev);
614int i915_ppgtt_init_ring(struct drm_i915_gem_request *req);
615void i915_ppgtt_release(struct kref *kref);
616struct i915_hw_ppgtt *i915_ppgtt_create(struct drm_device *dev,
617 struct drm_i915_file_private *fpriv);
618static inline void i915_ppgtt_get(struct i915_hw_ppgtt *ppgtt)
619{
620 if (ppgtt)
621 kref_get(&ppgtt->ref);
622}
623static inline void i915_ppgtt_put(struct i915_hw_ppgtt *ppgtt)
624{
625 if (ppgtt)
626 kref_put(&ppgtt->ref, i915_ppgtt_release);
627}
628
629void i915_check_and_clear_faults(struct drm_device *dev);
630void i915_gem_suspend_gtt_mappings(struct drm_device *dev);
631void i915_gem_restore_gtt_mappings(struct drm_device *dev);
632
633int __must_check i915_gem_gtt_prepare_object(struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj);
634void i915_gem_gtt_finish_object(struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj);
635
636static inline bool
637i915_ggtt_view_equal(const struct i915_ggtt_view *a,
638 const struct i915_ggtt_view *b)
639{
640 if (WARN_ON(!a || !b))
641 return false;
642
643 if (a->type != b->type)
644 return false;
645 if (a->type == I915_GGTT_VIEW_PARTIAL)
646 return !memcmp(&a->params, &b->params, sizeof(a->params));
647 return true;
648}
649
650size_t
651i915_ggtt_view_size(struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj,
652 const struct i915_ggtt_view *view);
653
654#endif
